document.docAuthor: Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M., Riera, Pamela, Pañinao-Monsálvez, Laura, Guzmán, Vicente Valdés & Henríquez-Piskulich, Patricia
document.masterDocTitle: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 104–109. Syritta flaviventris Mcquart, 1842: (104) visiting a ‘margarita’, Maipú (photo by Pablo Moreno). Tropidia notata (Bigot, 1882): (105) dorsal view (photo by Vicente Valdés). Tropidia nigricornis Philippi, 1865: (106) in situ lateral view and (107) dorsal view (Photos by Vicente Valdés). Tropidia flavimana (Philippi, 1865): (108) lateral and (109) dorsal view (photos by Vicente Valdés). Scale bars = 0.2 mm.

: (108) lateral and (109) dorsal view (photos by Vicente Valdés). Scale bars = 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality and data.
“ Illapel , Chile ” (T, ♂ , MNHNCL )
.

Chileand distribution. From Coquimbo to Ñuble region ( Fig. 110 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 110 . Distribution map of
Tropidia flavimana ( Philippi, 1865 )
(black circles);
Tropidia rubricornis Philippi, 1865
(violet circles);
Tropidia notata ( Bigot, 1882 )
(red circles);
Tropidia nigricornis Philippi, 1865
(green circles) and
Syritta flaviventris Mcquart, 1842
(blue circles) in Chile.

subSubSection.paragraph: Altitudinal range. From inland valleys to precordillera ecosystems (350– 1,400 m .a.s.l.).

Biology and notes.
Tropidia nigricornis
is associated with Mediterranean forests. It has been observed visiting
E. paniculatum
(R. Barahona-Segovia, pers. obs.). Other data about the biology or ecology of this species are unknown.
Conservation status. LC; EOO = 88,116 km 2 ; AOO = 64 km 2 and 16 localities (or subpopulations).
